channel.title: Research Data on
channel.description: Recent content in Research Data on

item.title: Disease data
item.description:
Disease data related to COVID-19

  • KEGG DISEASE: Diseases viewed as perturbed states of the molecular system

    KEGG DISEASE: Diseases viewed as perturbed states of the molecular system KEGG DISEASE is a database that collects data on diseases with known genetic factors (single gene disorder and multifactorial disease) and infectious diseases with known pathogen genome in a form that can be calculated. Each disease entry is identified by an accession number, called the "H" number, and is represented by a list of related pathways and pathogenic genes and that of environmental factors, diagnostic markers and molecules of such as therapeutic agents. The link above displays the entries for "COVID-19".

item.title: Genetic sequence data
item.description:
Genetic sequence data related to COVID-19

  • DDBJ ARSA

    DDBJ ARSA is a high-speed keyword search services on WWW and Web API provided by DDBJ within the National Institute of Genetics (NIG). It allows you to perform integrated search on major databases in the field of life sciences including the International Nucleotide Sequence Databases. The link is the results of the organism search for "Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2".

  • DDBJ SRA

    DDBJ SRA is a database for registering output data from next-generation sequencers and searching for registered data. It is operated by DDBJ in international cooperation with NCBI's SRA and EBI's ERA. The link is the results of the organism search for "Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2".

  • KEGG Virus

    KEGG Virus is a database operated by the Bioinformatics Center of the Institute for Chemical Research, Kyoto University, that summarises integrated data within KEGG regarding viral genes, genome sequences, biosynthetic pathways, diseases, etc. The link is the search results for "Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2".

  • KEGG Genome

    KEGG Genome is a KEGG database that extracts data from public databases such as RefSeq on all organisms for which the full genome sequence has been determined. The link is the search results for "Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2".

item.title: Imaging data
item.description:
Imaging data related to COVID-19

  • Imaging and Video Archive, National Institute of Infectious Diseases (NIID)

    This is an archive of images and video data related to the research in pathogens and infectious diseases provided by the National Institute of Infectious Diseases (NIID). It publishes the electron-micrographic images of the new coronavirus isolated at the NIID and the images of cytopathic effects of the virus. For the usage and specifications of the data, please refer to the description on the NIID website.

item.title: Literature
item.description:
Literature related to COVID-19

  • CiNii Articles

    CiNii Articles is a database service provided by the National Institute of Informatics (NII), and it searches data on academic papers published in academic societies' journal publications, universities' research bulletins, papers included in the Periodicals Index Database of the National Diet Library, etc. The link above is the search results of keywords related to COVID-19.

  • CiNii Books

    CiNii Books is a service that allows you to search for data on books (books, magazines, etc.) held by university libraries in Japan. It allows you to search for book data of about 10 million titles (totalled over 100 million books) held in 1200 university libraries and author data of about 1.5 million authors, which are accumulated in the online cataloguing system (NACSIS-CAT) operated by the National Institute of Informatics (NII). The link above is the search results of keywords related to COVID-19.

  • PubMed

    PubMed is a database operated by the U.S. National Institutes of Health (NIH), and it contains the bibliographic data (title, author name, journal title, abstracts, etc.) of MEDLINE and other journals in the field of life sciences. The literature that publish the full text for free are linked to the site that provides the full text. The link above takes you to a special page set up by the NIH for the search results of keywords related to COVID-19.

  • PubMed Central: PMC

    PubMed Central (PMC) is a digital archive for literature published in journals in the fields of biomedicine and life sciences operated by the U.S. National Institutes of Health (NIH). The link above is a special page that allows you to search by focusing on the literature related to COVID-19 and coronavirus.

  • Europe PMC

    Europe PMC is a collection of open literature in the field of life sciences provided by Europe EMBL-EBI. In collaboration with PMC and repositories around the world, it publishes bibliography and preprint information as well as papers. The above link is the COVID-19 related literature link located on its home page.

  • NBDC Blog

    NBDC Blog is a blog content for the field of life sciences and database integration provided by the National Bioscience Database Center (NBDC) of Japan Science and Technology Agency. In March 2020, the search results of resources in the field of life sciences were released under the title "Research Data Resources on New Coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) and New Coronavirus Infection (COVID-19)". Since then, it has been continuously updated.

  • National Diet Library Research Navi

    Research Navi is a collection site for research methods by theme and related links provided by the National Diet Library (NDL). The link above integrates and publishes a collection of websites of publishers, medical institutions, academic societies and newspaper publishers, libraries' efforts, and notices and notifications from Japanese government ministries, etc. regarding the new coronavirus. It also collects statistical data and survey methods on topics such as "how to investigate the effects of the new coronavirus on industries and labour relations."

  • Information page for the new coronavirus

    This page provides information on the new coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) published by the National Institute of Health Sciences. It covers information on COVID-19 vaccines and drug candidates, descriptions of COVID-19 diagnostic primer cross-reactivity analysis system, international trends in large-scale antibody testing, and food safety-related information provided by national and international institutions.

  • Information on important infectious diseases including COVID-19 in Japan

    This page publishes documents such as statements and recommendations on important infectious diseases in Japan that are produced by the Science Council of Japan. It also provides information on official materials related to the outbreak of COVID-19 in Japan, which can be difficult for international researchers to access.

  • PubAnnotation

    This is a repository of literature annotation that is made available by DBCLS. In particular, it integrates annotations for PubMed. At the link, you can annotate and browse the full-text data of CORD-19 (COVID-19 Open Research Dataset).

item.title: Protein data
item.description:
Protein data related to COVID-19

  • PDBj: Protein Data Bank Japan

    Protein Data Bank Japan (PDBj) cooperates with the U.S. Research Collaboratory for Structural Bioinformatics (RCSB), Biological Magnetic Resonance Data Bank (BMRB) and The Protein Data Bank in Europe (PDBe), and operates a three-dimensional structure database for biopolymers such as proteins, nucleic acids and sugars as an international PDB archive. It also provides various derived databases and their analysis tools. The special page provides structural information on the new coronavirus in Chinese and Korean as well as Japanese.

  • UniProt: The Universal Protein Resource

    UniProt is a leading database containing amino acid sequences and their functional data. It consists of three different databases: "UniProtKB", "UniRef" and "UniParc". On the special page, the data on amino acid sequence related to COVID-19 is published in a different cycle from UniProt itself.

  • TogoProt

    TogoProt is an integrated search system for protein-related databases provided by the National Bioscience Database Center (NBDC). In the keyword search, it first shows a list of protein family names in the menu. When you select your desired protein or family from the menu, the protein (family) data and the link will be displayed and then you can get to the desired entry in a database. The link above is the search results for "SARS-CoV-2".

  • jPOST

    jPOST is an integrated database for proteome that standardises, integrates and centrally manages various proteome data scattered within and outside Japan. It covers data such as post-translational modifications and absolute expression levels of various species. The linked page provides re-analysed data of the proteome related to COVID-19.

  • PRIDE: PRoteomics IDEntifications database

    PRIDE is a public repository for proteome data published by the European Bioinformatics Institute. The linked page publishes a list of identified data of peptides by mass spectrometry and proteins filtered by SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19.

item.title: Resource data
item.description:
Resource data related to COVID-19

  • Mouse strains for COVID-19 related researches

    RIKEN BioResource Research Center (BRC) is a unique repository in the world, as it collects and distributes bioresources of three different levels, i.e., genetic materials (genomic and cDNA clones) and cell lines of human and animal origins as well mouse strains. The research and developments on COVID-19 have been focusing on the following four subjects: 1) SARS-CoV-2 infection and proliferation, 2) Pathogenesis and host defense, 3) Disease progression to clinically severe cases and 4) Development of effective therapies of COVID-19 patients and preventive vaccines against SARS-CoV-2 infection. The RIKEN BRC provides the lists of mouse strains useful for the COVID-19 R&D.

  • SARS-CoV-2 relevant human genetic colones

    RIKEN BioResource Research Center (BRC) is a unique repository in the world, as it collects and distributes bioresources of three different levels, i.e., genetic materials (genomic and cDNA clones) and cell lines of human and animal origins as well mouse strains. The RIKEN BRC provides the lists of SARS-CoV-2 relevant human genetic colones useful for the COVID-19 R&D.

  • Cell line resources for COVID-19 researches

    RIKEN BioResource Research Center (BRC) is a unique repository in the world, as it collects and distributes bioresources of three different levels, i.e., genetic materials (genomic and cDNA clones) and cell lines of human and animal origins as well mouse strains. The RIKEN BRC provides the lists of cell lines useful for the COVID-19 R&D.
